focus_skills: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
Inference from sample statistics and margin of error

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><line x1='40' y1='260' x2='380' y2='260' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='40' y1='260' x2='40' y2='10' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='370' y='250' font-size='12' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>x</text><text x='25' y='20' font-size='12' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>y</text><text x='25' y='265' font-size='12'>0</text><text x='15' y='225' font-size='12'>50</text><text x='10' y='185' font-size='12'>100</text><text x='10' y='145' font-size='12'>150</text><text x='10' y='105' font-size='12'>200</text><text x='10' y='65' font-size='12'>250</text><text x='10' y='25' font-size='12'>300</text><text x='85' y='275' font-size='12'>5</text><text x='135' y='275' font-size='12'>10</text><text x='185' y='275' font-size='12'>15</text><text x='235' y='275' font-size='12'>20</text><text x='285' y='275' font-size='12'>25</text><text x='335' y='275' font-size='12'>30</text><path d='M40 20 L340 260' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' fill='none' /><circle cx='40' cy='20' r='3' fill='blue' /><circle cx='340' cy='260' r='3' fill='blue' /></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A line graph plotted on a Cartesian coordinate system. The x-axis represents 'Weeks since purchase' ranging from 0 to 30. The y-axis represents 'Value in dollars' ranging from 0 to 300. A blue line segment connects the point (0, 300) on the y-axis to the point (30, 0) on the x-axis, indicating a constant rate of decrease.
questions.question: The graph shown models the estimated value, in dollars, of a smartphone as a function of the number of weeks since it was purchased. What is the best interpretation of the <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi></math>-intercept of the graph in this context?

options.A: The initial value of the smartphone was <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>$</mo><mn>300</mn></math>.
options.B: The value of the smartphone <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>30</mn></math> weeks after it was purchased was <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>$</mo><mn>0</mn></math>.
options.C: The value of the smartphone decreases by <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>$</mo><mn>10</mn></math> each week.
options.D: The value of the smartphone decreases by <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>$</mo><mn>300</mn></math> every <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>30</mn></math> weeks.

questions.explanation:
To interpret the y-intercept, we look for the point where the input variable (x) is zero.

1. Identify the y-intercept on the graph: It is the point (0,300).
2. Interpret the coordinates in the context of the problem:
- The x-coordinate (0) represents 0 weeks since purchase (the time of purchase).
- The y-coordinate (300) represents the value of $300.

Therefore, the y-intercept signifies that the estimated value of the smartphone at the time of purchase was $300.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When asked for the meaning of the y-intercept, always replace 'x=0' with the context of the starting time or initial condition.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><line x1='20' y1='150' x2='380' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='200' y1='20' x2='200' y2='280' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='370' y='140' font-size='12' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>x</text><text x='210' y='30' font-size='12' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>y</text><text x='210' y='215' font-size='12'>-3</text><line x1='195' y1='210' x2='205' y2='210' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><path d='M80 30 Q200 390 320 30' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' fill='none' /><circle cx='200' cy='210' r='3' fill='blue' /></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A parabolic graph opening upwards with the vertex at (0, -3). The x-axis is the horizontal line at y=0, and the parabola's lowest point is 3 units below this axis.
questions.question: The graph shown will be translated up <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>3</mn></math> units. Which of the following will be the resulting graph?

options.A: <svg width='200' height='150' viewBox='0 0 200 150' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='200' height='150' fill='white' stroke='#e0e0e0'/><line x1='10' y1='75' x2='190' y2='75' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><line x1='100' y1='10' x2='100' y2='140' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><path d='M40 15 Q100 135 160 15' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' fill='none' /></svg>
options.B: <svg width='200' height='150' viewBox='0 0 200 150' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='200' height='150' fill='white' stroke='#e0e0e0'/><line x1='10' y1='75' x2='190' y2='75' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><line x1='100' y1='10' x2='100' y2='140' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><path d='M40 45 Q100 165 160 45' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' fill='none' /></svg>
options.C: <svg width='200' height='150' viewBox='0 0 200 150' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='200' height='150' fill='white' stroke='#e0e0e0'/><line x1='10' y1='75' x2='190' y2='75' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><line x1='100' y1='10' x2='100' y2='140' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><path d='M70 45 Q130 165 190 45' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' fill='none' /></svg>
options.D: <svg width='200' height='150' viewBox='0 0 200 150' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='200' height='150' fill='white' stroke='#e0e0e0'/><line x1='10' y1='75' x2='190' y2='75' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><line x1='100' y1='10' x2='100' y2='140' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><path d='M40 75 Q100 -45 160 75' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' fill='none' /></svg>

questions.explanation: Translating the graph up <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>3</mn></math> units adds <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>3</mn></math> to each <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi></math>-value. The original vertex was at <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Adding <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>3</mn></math> to the <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi></math>-coordinate gives <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Therefore, the new vertex is at <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, which is the origin.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><line x1='20' y1='150' x2='380' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><line x1='200' y1='20' x2='200' y2='280' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><text x='370' y='140' font-size='12' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>x</text><text x='210' y='30' font-size='12' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>y</text><path d='M80 30 Q200 390 320 30' stroke='gray' stroke-width='2' fill='none' stroke-dasharray='5,5' /><path d='M80 -30 Q200 330 320 -30' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' fill='none' /><text x='220' y='180' font-size='12' fill='gray'>Original (0, -3)</text><text x='220' y='130' font-size='12' fill='blue'>New (0, 0)</text><path d='M200 210 L200 158' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><defs><marker id='arrow' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='10' refX='0' refY='3' orient='auto' markerUnits='strokeWidth'><path d='M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z' fill='black' /></marker></defs></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The chart shows the original parabola (gray dashed line) with its vertex at (0, -3). An arrow points upwards to the new parabola (solid blue line) which has its vertex at the origin (0, 0), illustrating the translation of +3 units.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For vertical translations, add or subtract from the function's output; shifting 'up' means adding a positive number to the y-coordinate.

questions.question: The cost <math><mi>C</mi></math>, in dollars, to produce <math><mi>n</mi></math> widgets is given by <math><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>50</mn></math>. What does the 50 represent in this context?

options.A: The fixed cost to produce widgets.

questions.explanation: In the linear function, 50 is the y-intercept, representing the cost when n=0, which is the fixed cost.
questions.score_improvement_tip: In linear cost functions, the constant term is often the fixed cost, independent of production quantity.

questions.question: A shirt originally priced at $40 is on sale for 25% off. What is the sale price?
questions.explanation: 25% of $40 is $10, so sale price is $40 - $10 = $30.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To find discount, calculate percentage of original price and subtract from original.

questions.question: A ball is dropped from 32 feet and bounces to three-fourths the height each time. What is its maximum height, in feet, between the second and third bounce?
questions.explanation: First bounce: 32 * 3/4 = 24 feet. Second bounce: 24 * 3/4 = 18 feet. So between second and third is 18 feet.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For geometric sequences in bouncing problems, multiply by the ratio each time after the initial drop.

questions.question: The population of a town triples every 5 years. If there are 500 people now, which equation represents the population <math><mi>P</mi></math> after <math><mi>t</mi></math> years?
questions.explanation: Exponential growth: base 3 every 5 years, so P = 500 * 3^(t/5).
questions.score_improvement_tip: For exponential growth, use form initial * rate^(time/period).

questions.question: For the function <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>9</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>14</mn></math>, what is one x-intercept?
questions.explanation: Set to zero: x^2 - 9x + 14 = 0 factors to (x-2)(x-7)=0, so x=2 or 7. 2 is an option.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To find x-intercepts, solve f(x)=0 using factoring or quadratic formula.

questions.question: The graph of <math><mi>g</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math> is the graph of <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup></math> shifted left 4 units. Which equation defines <math><mi>g</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: Left shift by 4 replaces x with x+4.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For horizontal shifts, left means add to x inside the function.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question: Solve the system: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>, <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. What is <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: From the second equation, x = 3 - y. Substitute into the first: 3(3 - y) + 2y = 8 → 9 - 3y + 2y = 8 → 9 - y = 8 → y = 1. Then x = 3 - 1 = 2.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use substitution for systems when one equation is simple to solve for one variable.

questions.question: In a right triangle, the opposite side to a 30° angle is 5. What is the hypotenuse?
questions.explanation: In 30-60-90, opposite 30° is half hypotenuse, so hypotenuse = 10.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember special right triangle ratios: 30-60-90 is 1 : √3 : 2.

questions.question: The product of two positive integers is 224. If the first is 4 greater than three times the second, what is the smaller integer?
questions.explanation: Let second be y, first 3y+4, y(3y+4)=224 →<math><mn>3</mn><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>224</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Discriminant: <math><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>2688</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>2704</mn><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>52</mn><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>52</mn></mrow><mn>6</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>48</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>. Smaller is <math><mn>8</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For word problems leading to quadratics, set up equation and use quadratic formula, checking for positive integers.

questions.question: The function g is defined by g(z) = a/z -25, where <math><mi>a</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. What is the product of g(2a) and g(7a)?
questions.score_improvement_tip: When the argument is a multiple of a, the a terms cancel, making the expression independent of a; simplify before plugging in values.

questions.question: The table shows three values of x and corresponding g(x), where g is linear. Find the y-intercept of g(x). Table: x=-4, g=12; x=-2, g=8; x=0, g=4.
questions.explanation: Slope m=(8-12)/(-2+4) = (-4)/2 = -2. Using x=0, g=4, so y-intercept is 4.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For linear functions from table, find slope from two points, then use point-slope form to find intercept.

questions.question: The system <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>, <math><mi>x</mi><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math>. What is one value of x?
questions.explanation: <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>x</mi></math>, <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math> <math><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>25</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math> <math><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math><math><mo>→</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>,<math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mtext> or </mtext><mn>4</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For systems with linear and quadratic, substitute to form quadratic equation.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A survey of 100 people has a margin of error of ±5%. If 60% favor a policy, which is true?

options.B: The true proportion is between 55% and 65%.
options.C: The true proportion is less than 55%.
options.D: The sample is too small to infer.

questions.explanation: Margin of error means the true proportion is likely within 60% ±5%, i.e., 55% to 65%.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Margin of error gives the range around the sample statistic for the population parameter at a certain confidence level.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><circle cx='200' cy='150' r='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' fill='none' /><path d='M200 150 L300 150 A100 100 0 0 0 200 50 L200 150' fill='gray' /><text x='190' y='165' font-size='16' font-family='serif'>O</text><text x='250' y='145' font-size='12' font-family='sans-serif'>r = 8</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A circle with center O. Two radii form a 90-degree angle at the center, creating a shaded sector (a quadrant) in the top-right portion of the circle.
questions.question: The figure above shows a circle with center <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>O</mi></math> and a radius of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>8</mn></math>. The shaded region represents one quadrant of the circle. If a point is chosen at random from the interior of the circle, what is the probability that the point lies in the shaded region?
questions.explanation:
To find the probability, we compare the area of the target region to the total area of the circle.

1. **Identify the ratio of areas:**
The probability P is given by the ratio of the shaded area to the total area:
P=Area of Shaded RegionTotal Area of Circle
2. **Use the properties of a quadrant:**
A quadrant represents exactly 14 of a circle. Therefore, the area of the shaded region is 14 of the total area, regardless of the radius.

3. **Calculate:**
P=14=0.25
(Note: While the radius is 8, it cancels out in the ratio: 14π(82)π(82)=0.25).
questions.score_improvement_tip: For geometric probability involving sectors, the probability is simply the ratio of the sector's angle to 360 degrees (or the fraction of the circle), independent of the radius.

questions.question: Which is equivalent to <math><mfrac><mrow><mi>x</mi><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>16</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></math>?
questions.explanation: Numerator (x-4)(x+4), denominator x-4, cancels to x+4 for x≠4.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Simplify rational expressions by factoring and canceling common factors.

questions.question: Which value of x satisfies <math><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>></mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></math> and <math><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo><</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></math>?
questions.explanation: 2x - 3 > 1 → 2x > 4 → x > 2. x + 1 < 5 → x < 4. So 2 < x < 4, and 3 satisfies.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Solve each inequality separately, then find the intersection of solutions.

questions.question: Solve <math><mi>x</mi><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>11</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. What is the sum of the roots?
questions.explanation: Factors (x-1)(x-2)(x-3)=0, roots 1,2,3, sum 6. By Vieta for cubic x^3 - (sum)x^2 +... =0, sum=6.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For polynomials, use Vieta's formulas to find sum of roots directly from coefficients.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white' /><line x1='20' y1='280' x2='380' y2='280' stroke='black' /><line x1='20' y1='280' x2='20' y2='20' stroke='black' /><circle cx='50' cy='250' r='3' fill='black' /><circle cx='100' cy='220' r='3' fill='black' /><circle cx='150' cy='190' r='3' fill='black' /><circle cx='200' cy='160' r='3' fill='black' /><circle cx='250' cy='130' r='3' fill='black' /><circle cx='300' cy='100' r='3' fill='black' /><circle cx='350' cy='70' r='3' fill='black' /><path d='M20 280 L380 20' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5' /></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Scatterplot with points showing positive linear correlation, with a line of best fit.
questions.question: The scatterplot shows hours studied vs test score. Which best describes the relationship?
questions.explanation: The points rise from left to right, indicating a positive linear correlation.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for the overall trend in scatterplots; line of best fit helps identify linear relationships.
